stem: A 34-year-old G1P0 client at 34 weeks gestation is receiving a Magnesium Sulfate infusion for severe preeclampsia. Based on the documentation in the Critical OB Nephrology & Mag Clearance Log tab, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Acute decline in level of consciousness during Mag infusion.
Background: Severe Preeclampsia. Infusion started 4 hours ago.
Assessment: Client is difficult to arouse. Respiratory rate has dropped from 18 to 10.
Recommendation: Immediate stop and check for antidote.

tabs.title: Nephrology & Mag Log
tabs.content:
Assessment ItemCurrent FindingInterpretation
Urine Output (Last 2 hrs)15 mL TotalOliguria (Critical)
Deep Tendon ReflexesAbsent (0)Advanced Toxicity
Serum Magnesium Level10.2 mg/dLToxic (> 7-8)
Serum Creatinine2.8 mg/dL (High)Acute Kidney Injury

conditionOptions.text: Magnesium Toxicity secondary to Renal Failure

actionOptions.text: Immediately discontinue the Magnesium Sulfate infusion
Administer STAT IV Calcium Gluconate (the antidote)
Increase the IV fluid rate to 200 mL/hr to 'flush' the kidneys
Place the client in a Trendelenburg position to improve CPP

parameterOptions.text: Respiratory rate and Deep Tendon Reflexes (DTRs)
Hourly urine output and serum magnesium/creatinine levels
Daily measurement of fasting serum glucose
Presence of a positive Babinski sign

rationale.correct: This is Magnesium Toxicity secondary to Renal Failure (c2). Magnesium is excreted almost entirely by the kidneys. If a patient with preeclampsia develops oliguria (15 mL in 2 hrs), the Magnesium builds up to toxic levels (10.2). This leads to depressed CNS, absent reflexes, and respiratory depression (RR 10). Priority #1 is stopping the drug (a1) and Priority #2 is the antidote (a2). Monitoring must focus on the 'Toxic' signs (p1) and the 'Cause' (Oliguria) (p2).
clinicalPearls: If the urine output is < 30 mL/hr, you MUST notify the provider and likely reduce or stop the Magnesium.
Calcium Gluconate is the direct antagonist to Magnesium at the neuromuscular junction.
Reflexes go away FIRST; Respirations go away SECOND; The heart stops LAST.

questionTrap.trap: Thinking the patient is having a stroke because they are 'lethargic'.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Check the reflexes! If they are absent (0), and the RR is low, it's Magnesium. If they were hyperreflexic (4+), it might be a CNS stroke/seizure.

mnemonic.title: BURP
mnemonic.expansion: B-BP drops. U-Urine output drops. R-Respiratory rate drops. P-Patellar reflex absent.
